Detailed Description

Non-primitive functions required by eval().

These functions can be written in terms of the lisp understood by eval() and they make writing eval() simpler. They are used for handling the environment and function arguments.

Definition in file utils.c.

Function Documentation

sexp append ( sexp  list_a,
sexp  list_b 
)

Concatenate two lists.

Create a list by joining two lists together.

Parameters:
list_a A list to become the head of new list.
list_b A list to become the tail of new list.
Returns:
A list with the elements of list_a followed by the elements of list_b.

sexp equal ( sexp  expr_a,
sexp  expr_b 
)

Compare two lisp expressions.

Expressions expr_a and expr_b are equal if they have the same structure.

Parameters:
expr_a A symbolic lisp expression.
expr_b A symbolic lisp expression.
Returns:
't if expr_a and expr_b are isomorphic, 'nil otherwise.
Note:
This function is not used by eval(). Instead, it is useful for testing.

sexp null ( sexp  expr  ) 

Test for 'nil.

Predicate to test for 'nil atom. In lisp, 'nil is used for false and the empty list.

Parameters:
expr Arbitrary lisp symbolic expression.
Returns:
't if expr is the 'nil atom, 'nil otherwise.

Definition at line 40 of file utils.c.

Referenced by append(), and pair().

sexp pair ( sexp  list_a,
sexp  list_b 
)

Build a dictionary.

Build a dictionary from a list of keys list_a and a list of values list_b. The dictionary is in the same order as list_a; it is not sorted. An example in lisp syntax:

 > (pair '(value key) '(3 definition))
 ((value . 3) (key . definition))

Parameters:
list_a A list of keys.
list_b A list of values.
Returns:
A list of (key . value) pairs.
